Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Hollow Nanoparticle Synthesis - Templating Electrochemically Evolved Hydrogen Nanobubbles
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY
This collaborative research between the University of Texas at Arlington and Bryn Mawr College will develop a fundamental understanding of the bubble template synthesis method, a new nanoparticle synthesis process. In this method, electrochemically evolved hydrogen nanobubbles are used as reducing agents and templates to form metal hollow nanoparticles. This new synthesis concept possesses the potential to become a general route to varieties of nanostructures. In this project funded by the Solid State and Materials Chemistry Program, in situ synchrotron x-ray diffraction, atomic force microscopy (AFM) and electron microscopy (SEM and TEM) will be employed to investigate the formation of nanobubbles and nanoparticles at different growth stages, and the synthesis of nanoparticles with more complicated structures and from different materials will be studied. First, the reaction mechanism and kinetics of metal reduction around hydrogen nanobubbles will be investigated by in situ monitoring the metal deposition using synchrotron X-ray diffraction. The hypothesis of "the reaction rate is higher for smaller bubbles" will be tested through electron microscopy analysis of nanoparticles formed with different synthesis parameters. Then, the formation mechanism of electrochemically evolved hydrogen nanobubbles will be studied by in situ detecting the formation of nanobubbles on non-conductive areas on stripe pattern electrode surfaces using AFM. With Au nanoparticles as an indicator, the effects of the surface properties of supports and additives in electrolytes (such as surfactants and hydrogen evolution enhancers) on nanobubble formation will be studied using electron microscopy analysis. Finally, the synthesis of hollow nanoparticles of different electroless-depositable metals such as Pt, Pd and Ag and nanoparticles with more complicated structures such as multi-shells and half spheres will be explored.

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY
Nanotechnology is considered as one of the most potentially valuable technologies for U.S. in the global economic competition. As an important part of nanotechnology, metallic nanoparticles are widely used as catalysts in energy conversion and chemical industry, as imaging and therapeutic agents in biomedical applications, as building blocks in electronic and optoelectronic devices, and in many other areas. Through a systematic study on a new nanoparticle synthesis process - the bubble template synthesis, this research project funded by the Solid State and Materials Chemistry Program will lead to advances in the understanding of nanoparticle formation mechanisms, providing essential information for controlling the synthesis process to achieve the desired properties of nanoparticles. In addition, the new synthesis process can also be utilized as a convenient tool for studies on very small gas bubbles (nanobubbles) in liquid. This will have many important impacts on a wide range of bubble-related applications, from hydrogen generation and water electrolysis to the design of fluidic microchannels and nanodevices. This research program is integrated with a multi-layered education and outreach program, including course development for undergraduate nanotechnology education, interdisciplinary student training, summer camps for K-12 students, and outreach activities through annual "Extending Your Horizon" (EYH) conference for Philadelphia local middle school girls. Special emphasis has been placed on broadening the participation of both women and underrepresented Hispanic students in science and engineering by providing opportunities to women undergraduate students in Bryn Mawr College and Hispanic high school and college students in Texas with conducting state-of-the-art nanotechnology research in this project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nanotechnology is considered as one of the most potentially valuable technologies for U.S. in the global economic competition. As an important part of nanotechnology, metallic nanoparticles are widely used as catalysts in energy conversion and chemical industry, as imaging and therapeutic agents in biomedical applications, as building blocks in electronic and optoelectronic devices, and in many other areas. Through this research project funded by the Solid State and Materials Chemistry Program in NSF, we have conducted a systematic study on a new nanoparticle synthesis process – the bubble template synthesis, in which electrochemically evolved hydrogen nanobubbles act as template and reducing agent to produce hollow nanoparticles. This project has advanced our understanding of nanoparticle formation mechanisms, providing essential information for controlling the synthesis process to achieve the desired properties of these hollow nanoparticles. We have successfully adopted Spectral Domain Phase Sensitive Interferometry (SDPSI) to in-situ monitor the formation process of hollow gold (Au) nanoparticles, including electrochemical evolution of hydrogen nanobubbles and the electroless deposition of Au around the hydrogen bubbles. We found that hydrogen nanobubbles appear 200 seconds after the application of the potential for hydrogen evolution.  This is a direct confirmation of the theory that a supersaturation of hydrogen molecules is needed to initiate bubble formation. It has also been found that significant Au deposition does not start immediately after the formation of hydrogen nanobubbles. But after the deposition starts, Au grow rapidly. This can be explained that Au deposition goes through typical nucleation and growth process. Once nucleation starts, the deposition proceeds rapidly.

The SDPSI method developed in this project has the potential to become a new general tool for in-situ study of electrochemical processes on a solid substrate in liquid. Such processes are widely used in semiconductor industry and biological and chemical sensor industry. This new optical method has two unique advantages over other in-situ probing approaches for electrochemical processes such as synchrotron X-ray diffraction, transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and atomic force microscopy (AFM): 1) No special electrochemical cells are required, and electrochemical process is conducted under normal experimental conditions. 2) The light (from visible to near infrared) usually does not interfere with the electrochemical process. We have demonstrated the extremely high sensitivity of the SDPSI method; we have successfully detected the deposition and stripping of a monolayer of atoms on a metal surface in liquid (monolayer of copper atoms on gold surface).

In addition, during this project, we developed a unique process to coat hollow Au nanoparticles with other precious metals.  In this method, a copper layer is first coated to Au nanoparticles by a simple but robust electroless deposition process. Then, the Cu layer can be readily replaced by less reactive metals through simple replacement reactions using aqueous solution containing metal ions without any other additives. This Cu-mediated process provides a facile way to incorporate metal isotopes into Au nanoparticles from solutions with trace level concentrations to form radioactive nanoparticles. Radioactive Pd isotopes, which are currently used in clinical practice for the treatment of cancers, have been efficiently incorporated on the surface of hollow Au nanoparticles. Such radioactive nanoparticles (nanoseeds) can be intratumorally injected into tumor sites, serving as internal radiation sources for radiation therapy. The size of the nanoseed, ~150nm in diameter, is large enough to prevent nanoseeds from diffusing into other areas while still small enough to allow them to homogeneously distribute inside the tumor. The radiation is fully contained inside the tumor, so therefore dramatically reduce adverse side effects. This novel radiation therapy potentially offers a new, much more effective treatment for several deadliest cancers such as brain tumor and liver cancer.

Total 8 papers in peer-reviewed journals have been published, and 3 presentations have been given in national and international conferences.

This research project has also been integrated with a multi-layered education and outreach program, including course development for undergraduate nanotechnology education, student training in an interdisciplinary field, and summer camps for K-12 students. Through this project, we have developed four experimental modules for an experiment-oriented nanotechnology course, 'MSE 4320/5320 Nanoscale Materials'. Every year; about 15 students enrolled in this class. Total four PhD students, two MS students, and one undergraduate students have participated in this project. They got trained on the whole nanotechnology research process, from experiment design, implementation to data analysis.  We have participated in annual summer camps organized by the department with the sponsorship of ASM International and the North Texas Chapter of ASM. Every year, about 25 students got into our labs, and exposed to the research activities related to this project.


Last Modified: 11/29/2016
Modified by: Yaowu Hao
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Nanotechnology is considered as one of the most potentially valuable technologies for U.S. in the global economic competition. As an important part of nanotechnology, metallic nanoparticles are widely used as catalysts in energy conversion and chemical industry, as imaging and therapeutic agents in biomedical applications, as building blocks in electronic and optoelectronic devices, and in many other areas. Through this research project funded by the Solid State and Materials Chemistry Program in NSF, we have conducted a systematic study on a new nanoparticle synthesis process – the bubble template synthesis, in which electrochemically evolved hydrogen nanobubbles act as template and reducing agent to produce hollow nanoparticles. This project has advanced our understanding of nanoparticle formation mechanisms, providing essential information for controlling the synthesis process to achieve the desired properties of these hollow nanoparticles. We have successfully adopted Spectral Domain Phase Sensitive Interferometry (SDPSI) to in-situ monitor the formation process of hollow gold (Au) nanoparticles, including electrochemical evolution of hydrogen nanobubbles and the electroless deposition of Au around the hydrogen bubbles. We found that hydrogen nanobubbles appear 200 seconds after the application of the potential for hydrogen evolution. This is a direct confirmation of the theory that a supersaturation of hydrogen molecules is needed to initiate bubble formation. It has also been found that significant Au deposition does not start immediately after the formation of hydrogen nanobubbles. But after the deposition starts, Au grow rapidly. This can be explained that Au deposition goes through typical nucleation and growth process. Once nucleation starts, the deposition proceeds rapidly. Such processes are widely used in semiconductor industry and biological and chemical sensor industry. We have demonstrated the extremely high sensitivity of the SDPSI method; we have successfully detected the deposition and stripping of a monolayer of atoms on a metal surface in liquid (monolayer of copper atoms on gold surface). In addition, during this project, we developed a unique process to coat hollow Au nanoparticles with other precious metals. In this method, a copper layer is first coated to Au nanoparticles by a simple but robust electroless deposition process. Radioactive Pd isotopes, which are currently used in clinical practice for the treatment of cancers, have been efficiently incorporated on the surface of hollow Au nanoparticles. Total 8 papers in peer-reviewed journals have been published, and 3 presentations have been given in national and international conferences. This research project has also been integrated with a multi-layered education and outreach program, including course development for undergraduate nanotechnology education, student training in an interdisciplinary field, and summer camps for K-12 students. Through this project, we have developed four experimental modules for an experiment-oriented nanotechnology course, 'MSE 4320/5320 Nanoscale Materials'. Every year; about 15 students enrolled in this class. Total four PhD students, two MS students, and one undergraduate students have participated in this project. They got trained on the whole nanotechnology research process, from experiment design, implementation to data analysis. We have participated in annual summer camps organized by the department with the sponsorship of ASM International and the North Texas Chapter of ASM. Every year, about 25 students got into our labs, and exposed to the research activities related to this project. Last Modified: 11/29/2016 Submitted by: Yaowu Hao
